ingredients.nutritionalValue: Very low in calories; excellent source of vitamin K and a good source of antioxidants like apigenin. Contains dietary fiber and provides small amounts of vitamin C, potassium, and folate.
A good source of fiber, potassium, calcium, and copper. Rich in antioxidants and plant compounds like lignin and tannins, which may help combat free radicals. Often used like a vegetable.

Highly concentrated in antioxidants and vitamins A and C. Not consumed in large quantities; primarily used as a spice for its licorice-like flavor and shikimic acid, a compound used in antiviral medications.
The seeds are used for color and mild flavor, not for significant nutritional intake. They contain carotenoids (like bixin and norbixin), tocotrienols, and some antioxidant properties.
Low in calories and fat. Contains B-vitamins, selenium, potassium, copper, and a small amount of vitamin D. A source of antioxidants and beta-glucans, which support immune health.
A good source of protein, fiber, B-vitamins (especially niacin and riboflavin), and minerals like iron, zinc, and potassium. Contains antioxidants and may help lower cholesterol.
Processed sago palm pith. A pure source of carbohydrates with minimal protein, fat, or micronutrients. Primarily used as a starchy staple or thickener.
Almost pure starch (carbohydrates). Provides quick energy but is devoid of significant protein, vitamins, or minerals. Commonly used for pearls and puddings.
An excellent source of plant-based protein and fiber, which aids digestion and blood sugar control. Rich in iron, folate, manganese, and antioxidants.
A spice rich in iron, a good source of manganese, calcium, and magnesium. Contains antioxidants and compounds that may aid digestion and provide antimicrobial benefits.
A powerful spice rich in antioxidants (polyphenols). Contains anti-inflammatory properties and may help lower blood sugar levels by improving insulin sensitivity.
Made from dried, ground peppers. Exceptionally high in vitamin A (from beta-carotene) and vitamin E. Contains capsaicinoids, which have antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
An excellent source of manganese. Very rich in antioxidants, including eugenol, which has strong anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties.
Dried form is nutritionally concentrated. High in B-vitamins, vitamin D (if exposed to UV light), copper, selenium, and potassium. A great source of umami flavor.
Very low in calories. A good source of iron, fiber, and antioxidants. Valued more for its gelatinous texture in cooking than for dense micronutrient content.
Extremely nutrient-dense. An excellent source of vitamin K, vitamin C, and vitamin A (from beta-carotene). Contains antioxidants like flavonoids and volatile oils.
A good source of vitamin K, vitamin A, and vitamin C. Contains antioxidants that may help protect against cellular damage and support heart health.
A complete plant-based protein made from soybeans. A good source of iron, calcium, manganese, and phosphorus. Contains isoflavones, which are beneficial phytoestrogens.
A nutrient powerhouse. Very low in calories but high in vitamins A, C, and K. Also provides folate, calcium, and potassium. Contains antioxidants like quercetin.
Higher in fat and cholesterol than chicken eggs but also more nutrient-dense per gram. Rich in vitamin B12, riboflavin, selenium, and iron.
Fermented black beans are a good source of protein and iron. High in sodium due to the salting process. Contains isoflavones and may have probiotic benefits from fermentation.
Fermented fish paste. High in protein, sodium, and calcium (from small, edible bones). Contains omega-3 fatty acids but its high salt content should be considered.
Fermented shrimp or krill. Very high in sodium and cholesterol. Provides some protein, calcium, and iron, but typically used in small amounts as a seasoning.
A type of gourd. Low in calories and a good source of dietary fiber. Provides vitamin C, vitamin A, and minerals like magnesium and potassium.
Very low in fat and calories. An excellent source of lean protein, selenium, vitamin B12, and the antioxidant astaxanthin, which gives it its pink color.
A herb very high in antioxidants, including rosmarinic acid and thymol. A good source of vitamin K, iron, calcium, and has antimicrobial properties.
Contains menthol, which aids digestion and provides a cooling sensation. A good source of vitamin A and antioxidants. Often used medicinally for IBS relief.
Rich in vitamin K, vitamin A (from beta-carotene), and antioxidants. Contains essential oils like eugenol which have anti-inflammatory properties.
A good source of vitamin C, vitamin K, and manganese. Provides fiber, folate, and silicon, which is important for bone health and connective tissue formation.
Can be eaten whole. A good source of vitamin C, vitamin K, and vitamin A. Provides fiber and plant-based iron.
A nutritious lettuce variety. A good source of vitamins A and K, and folate. Higher in nutrients and fiber than iceberg lettuce.
Unique source of betalains, powerful antioxidants with anti-inflammatory properties. Rich in folate, manganese, potassium, and dietary nitrates which may improve blood flow.
Packed with antioxidants, including anthocyanins (which give it its color) and vitamin C. A very good source of vitamin K and fiber.
Very low in calories. A good source of vitamin C and provides small amounts of potassium and folate. Contains compounds that may support liver and digestive health.
Concentrated in flavor and nutrients compared to larger tomatoes. An excellent source of the antioxidant lycopene, vitamin C, and vitamin K.
Similar nutrition to full-sized potatoes: a good source of potassium, vitamin C, and vitamin B6. The skin provides fiber. They are primarily a starchy carbohydrate.
Higher in fat and collagen compared to lean cuts. Provides protein, niacin, and selenium. Often used for flavoring stocks and soups.
A very lean source of high-quality protein. Low in fat and an excellent source of niacin, vitamin B6, selenium, and phosphorus.
Higher in fat than breast meat due to the skin and dark meat. A good source of protein, niacin, and selenium.
An extremely nutrient-dense organ meat. Exceptionally high in vitamin A, vitamin B12, iron, and folate. Also a great source of copper and riboflavin.
Very high in collagen, which converts to gelatin when cooked. Provides protein, calcium, and cartilage. Valued for making rich, gelatinous broths.
A mix of dark meat (thigh and drumstick). Higher in fat and iron than white meat. A good source of protein, zinc, and B vitamins.
Dark meat that is more flavorful and moist than breast due to higher fat content. A good source of protein, iron, and zinc.
A lean organ meat. An excellent source of protein, iron, zinc, selenium, and B vitamins, particularly B12. Also a great source of CoQ10.
A good source of protein and contains some iron and B vitamins. Higher in cholesterol and saturated fat than lean muscle meats.
Includes the thigh and drumstick. Nutritionally similar to chicken legs and thighs: good protein, higher in fat than breast, source of iron and zinc.
Primarily used for making stock. Provides some protein, collagen, and minerals from the bones and tissues, but little meat.
A muscular organ meat, very lean and high in protein. A good source of iron, zinc, and B vitamins, particularly B12.
A moderately fatty cut of pork. A good source of high-quality protein, thiamine, niacin, vitamin B6, zinc, and selenium.
Very high in collagen, connective tissue, and fat. When cooked slowly, it releases gelatin, making broths rich and sticky. Provides some protein and minerals.
One of the leanest cuts of pork. An excellent source of high-quality protein, thiamine, vitamin B6, phosphorus, and niacin.
One of the fattiest cuts of pork. Provides high-quality protein and is rich in B vitamins (especially thiamine) and selenium, but also high in saturated fat.
A fatty cut with connective tissue. A good source of protein, zinc, selenium, and B vitamins. The high fat content contributes significantly to its flavor.
A lean to moderately fatty cut from the hind leg. A good source of protein, thiamine, niacin, vitamin B6, zinc, and phosphorus.
Used for dishes like sisig. Fatty and gelatinous. Provides protein, B vitamins, and minerals from the various tissues, but is high in saturated fat and cholesterol.
Extremely nutrient-dense. One of the best dietary sources of vitamin A, vitamin B12, iron, and copper. Also rich in riboflavin and folate.
Includes various organs (e.g., kidneys, intestines). Generally good sources of protein, iron, and B vitamins. Cholesterol and nutrient content vary by specific organ.
A flavorful cut from the shoulder. Moderately fatty with connective tissue, making it good for slow cooking. A good source of protein, iron, zinc, and B12.
A leaner cut from the chuck. A good source of high-quality protein, iron, zinc, vitamin B12, and niacin.
A fatty cut with connective tissue that becomes tender when slow-cooked. Rich in protein, collagen (converts to gelatin), iron, and zinc.
The bone marrow is rich in fat, calories, and collagen. It contains conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) and provides some vitamin B12 and adiponectin.
A lean and tough cut that benefits from slow cooking or marinating. A good source of protein, iron, zinc, and creatine.
A very flavorful and fatty cut. High in protein, iron, zinc, and B vitamins. The high fat content contributes to its rich taste and higher calorie count.
A popular, tender, and relatively lean cut. An excellent source of high-quality protein, vitamin B12, zinc, selenium, and iron.
The most tender cut of beef, very lean. An excellent source of protein, vitamin B12, niacin, zinc, and selenium.
A lean and flavorful cut, but can be tough. Best when marinated and cooked quickly. A great source of protein, iron, and vitamin B6.
Meat from the head is often used in stews and soups. It can be fatty and gelatinous. Provides protein, collagen, and minerals from the cheeks and other tissues.
An organ meat that is high in fat and cholesterol but also very nutritious. An excellent source of vitamin B12, zinc, iron, and choline.
A leafy green rich in mucilage, which aids digestion. An excellent source of vitamin A, vitamin C, calcium, and iron. Also contains antioxidants.
A good source of omega-3 and omega-6 fatty acids. Rich in antioxidants, vitamin A, and vitamin C. Also provides iron and manganese.
Edible chili pepper leaves. A good source of vitamins A and C, calcium, and iron. Have a slightly peppery flavor and are used in soups and stews.
Highly nutritious leafy green. An excellent source of vitamin K, vitamin A, and antioxidant polyphenols. A good plant-based source of iron and calcium.
Used medicinally and in cooking. Like the fruit, they contain compounds like charantin and polypeptide-p that may help lower blood sugar levels. Also provide vitamin A and C.
Low in fat and calories. An excellent source of protein, vitamin B12, selenium, and riboflavin. Contains antioxidants and is a good source of copper.
Small fish eaten whole, providing calcium from their bones. A good source of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA/DHA), protein, selenium, and niacin.
A type of seaweed. A good source of vitamins A and C, calcium, iron, and magnesium. Contains natural compounds that may have anti-diabetic and antioxidant effects.
A gelatin substitute derived from seaweed. Almost pure soluble fiber. It is very low in calories, fat-free, and provides no significant vitamins or minerals.
Exceptionally rich in zinc, which is crucial for immune function. Also an excellent source of vitamin B12, copper, and selenium. Provides high-quality protein.
An excellent source of lean protein, vitamin B12, and iron. Extremely rich in selenium and also provides potassium and omega-3 fatty acids.
A type of shellfish. Nutritionally similar to clams/mussels: a good source of protein, iron, zinc, selenium, and vitamin B12.
Likely refers to freshwater shellfish. A good source of protein, low in fat. Provides minerals like iron, zinc, and selenium.
A small sea snail. A lean source of protein. Provides minerals like iron, magnesium, and selenium, and some omega-3 fatty acids.
Not a common food item. Limited nutritional data. Likely provides protein and some minerals from its tissues.
A type of shellfish/mollusk. Likely a good source of lean protein, vitamin B12, iron, and other trace minerals like zinc and selenium.
A small dried fish. Concentrated source of protein, calcium (if bones are eaten), and omega-3 fatty acids. High in sodium due to the drying and salting process.
A small dried fish. Concentrated source of protein, calcium (if bones are eaten), and omega-3 fatty acids. High in sodium due to the drying and salting process.
A type of dried fish. High in protein and provides calcium and phosphorus from the bones. Very high in sodium due to the preservation process.
Dried form is a concentrated source of protein, calcium (from bones), and omega-3 fatty acids. Very high in sodium and a good source of niacin.
A type of small, thin dried fish. High in protein and calcium. Like all dried fish, it is very high in sodium.
Chewy and flavorful. A good source of protein, low in fat. Contains some copper, selenium, and vitamin B12. High in sodium and cholesterol.
A type of dried fish. Provides high-quality protein, essential amino acids, and minerals like calcium and phosphorus. High in sodium.
Dried grouper is a concentrated source of protein and omega-3 fatty acids. Provides selenium, vitamin B6, and potassium. High in sodium.
A dried fish. Good source of protein and provides some omega-3s, calcium, and iron. The drying process significantly increases its sodium content.
Dried parrotfish is a lean source of protein. Provides some vitamins and minerals but is primarily valued for its shelf-stable protein and flavor. High in sodium.
A very small dried fish. Eaten whole, providing an excellent source of calcium from the bones. High in protein and very high in sodium.
A type of small dried fish. Nutritionally similar to other small dried fish: high in protein, calcium, and sodium.
A type of dried fish. A concentrated source of protein and provides minerals like iron and calcium. The salting process makes it high in sodium.
Dried round scad is a good source of protein, omega-3 fatty acids, calcium, and iron. The preservation process makes it very high in sodium.
Dried sardines are nutrient-dense. Eaten whole, they provide excellent calcium and phosphorus. Rich in protein, omega-3s, and vitamin D. Very high in sodium.
A small, flat dried fish. Eaten whole, providing calcium and phosphorus. A good source of protein and omega-3s, but high in sodium.
Made from rice flour. Very high in carbohydrates for energy. Low in fat, fiber, and protein. Typically enriched with iron.
Fresh rice noodles. Lower in calories than dried noodles due to higher water content. A good source of carbohydrates but low in other nutrients.
A type of egg noodle. Provides carbohydrates from wheat flour, protein and fat from eggs. Often contains added salt.
Made from mung bean starch. Pure carbohydrate. Gluten-free and virtually fat-free, but also lacks significant protein, vitamins, or minerals.
A type of wheat-based noodle. Provides carbohydrates, some protein from wheat gluten, and is often enriched with B vitamins like folate and iron.
A yellow wheat flour noodle. A source of carbohydrates and some protein. Often fortified with iron and B vitamins.
Very thin wheat flour noodles. A good source of carbohydrates. Often enriched with iron and B vitamins like niacin and thiamine.
Made from wheat flour and water. Primarily a source of carbohydrates. Low in fat, fiber, and protein unless made with egg.
White rice. A primary source of carbohydrates and energy. The milling process removes the bran and germ, reducing fiber, vitamins, and minerals compared to brown rice.
Typically white rice. A staple food providing energy primarily from carbohydrates. Often enriched with iron and B vitamins to replace some lost nutrients.
Whole grain. Higher in fiber than white rice. A good source of antioxidants like lutein and zeaxanthin, which are good for eye health.
Whole grain. Provides more fiber and nutrients than white rice. A good source of complex carbohydrates, magnesium, and some B vitamins.
A nutritional powerhouse. Excellent source of vitamins C and K. High in fiber, folate, potassium, and sulforaphane, a potent antioxidant with cancer-fighting properties.
Low in calories, high in fiber. A good source of vitamin K, vitamin C, and folate. Contains antioxidants like anthocyanins in red cabbage.
Very versatile and low in carbs. An excellent source of vitamin C and vitamin K. Contains choline, which is important for brain health, and various antioxidants.
Very high in water content, making it low in calories. Provides some vitamin K, vitamin A (from beta-carotene), and folate.
A popular leafy green. A good source of vitamin A, vitamin C, and iron. Also contains magnesium, potassium, and some calcium.
Leafy greens with a peppery flavor. An excellent source of vitamins K, A, and C. Also provides antioxidants and may have anti-inflammatory effects.
A type of Chinese cabbage. Very low in calories. A rich source of vitamins A, C, and K. Also provides calcium, potassium, and folate.
Similar to pechay. A cruciferous vegetable rich in vitamins A, C, and K. Provides antioxidants and is a good source of fiber for digestive health.
Known for its bitter taste and potential blood sugar-lowering properties (contains charantin and polypeptide-p). A good source of vitamin C and vitamin A.
Low in calories. A good source of fiber, antioxidants, particularly nasunin (in the skin), which protects brain cells, and chlorogenic acid.
Extremely high in water content (over 95%), making it very hydrating and low in calories. Provides small amounts of vitamin K and potassium.
A mild-flavored gourd. Low in calories and a good source of vitamin C, vitamin A, and manganese. Contains dietary fiber.
Very light and low in calories. High in water content, fiber, vitamin C, and calcium. Known for its cooling and diuretic properties.
A good source of fiber, vitamin C, vitamin K, and folate. Contains mucilage, which thickens stews and may aid digestion.
A winter squash. Rich in beta-carotene (converts to vitamin A), vitamin C, and fiber. Also provides potassium and antioxidants like lutein.
A low-calorie squash. A good source of vitamin C, folate, and fiber. Also provides small amounts of vitamin K and potassium.
An excellent source of the antioxidant lycopene, linked to reduced heart disease and cancer risk. Also provides vitamin C, potassium, and folate.
A small citrus fruit. Extremely high in vitamin C. Also provides antioxidants and a small amount of potassium. Used more for juice than eating whole.
Very high in capsaicin, which boosts metabolism and has pain-relieving properties. An excellent source of vitamins A and C, and antioxidants.
A mild to medium chili pepper. A good source of vitamins A and C, and capsaicinoids. Contains antioxidants that can reduce inflammation.
An excellent source of vitamin C (especially red peppers) and vitamin A. Also provides vitamin E, folate, and fiber. Low in calories.
A good source of fiber, protein, vitamins A, C, and K, and folate. Also provides minerals like manganese and magnesium.
A good source of vitamins C, K, and A. Provides fiber, folate, and silicon, which is important for bone health and connective tissue formation.
A starchy vegetable. Higher in calories than green beans. A good source of protein, fiber, vitamins A, C, and K, and manganese.
When dried, they are a concentrated source of plant-based protein, fiber, and folate. Also provide iron, magnesium, and potassium.
High in healthy monounsaturated fats and protein. A good source of biotin, copper, niacin, folate, and manganese. Also contain resveratrol.
Famous for their high beta-carotene (vitamin A) content, which is good for vision. A good source of fiber, vitamin K, and potassium.
Very low in calories. A good source of vitamin C and provides small amounts of potassium and folate. Contains compounds that may support liver health.
Sprouting increases vitamin content (like vitamin C) and decreases antinutrients. A good source of protein, fiber, and folate.
A root vegetable with a crisp, juicy texture. Very high in vitamin C and a good source of fiber. Low in calories and starch.
A starchy vegetable. A good source of potassium, vitamin C, and vitamin B6. The skin provides fiber.
An excellent source of beta-carotene (vitamin A). Also high in vitamin C, manganese, and fiber. Has a lower glycemic index than white potatoes.
A tropical root vegetable very high in carbohydrates. A source of vitamin C and manganese, but must be cooked properly to remove cyanogenic glycosides.
A starchy root vegetable. Easily digestible, making it good for weaning babies and those with digestive issues. Provides some potassium and iron.
Known for its vibrant purple color from antioxidants called anthocyanins. A good source of vitamin C, potassium, and complex carbohydrates.
The corm is high in starch and must be cooked to remove calcium oxalate crystals. A good source of fiber, vitamin E, vitamin B6, and potassium.
Contain quercetin, a flavonoid antioxidant with anti-inflammatory effects. A good source of vitamin C, vitamin B6, and manganese.
Similar to red onions. Contain antioxidants and organosulfur compounds. A good source of vitamin C, vitamin B6, and manganese.
The green part is rich in vitamin K. Provides vitamin C, vitamin A, and folate. Has a milder flavor than bulb onions.
Famous for allicin, a compound with potent medicinal properties, including antibacterial and cardiovascular benefits. A good source of manganese, vitamin B6, and vitamin C.
Contains gingerol, a bioactive compound with powerful anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects. Can help treat nausea and may reduce muscle pain.
A starchy banana. Higher in calories and carbohydrates than sweet bananas. A good source of potassium, vitamin C, and dietary fiber.
A common dessert banana. A good source of potassium, which is vital for heart health and blood pressure control. Provides vitamin B6 and vitamin C.
A vitamin-rich banana variety. An excellent source of potassium and vitamin B6. Also provides vitamin C and dietary fiber.
A sweet, soft banana. A good source of quick energy from carbohydrates. Provides potassium, magnesium, and vitamin B6.
A cooking banana, similar to saba. Starchy and used in savory dishes. A good source of potassium, vitamin A, and vitamin C.
A type of banana. Like other varieties, it is a good source of potassium, vitamin B6, and provides sustainable energy from carbohydrates.
A good source of fiber, particularly pectin, which is beneficial for gut health. Provides vitamin C and various antioxidants.
Famous for its vitamin C content. Also a good source of fiber, folate, and antioxidants like flavonoids which may improve heart health.
Primarily used for its juice, which is an excellent source of vitamin C. Also contains antioxidants and may aid iron absorption.
Unripe mango is higher in vitamin C and starch, which converts to sugar as it ripens. A good source of vitamin A and fiber.
A ripe, sweet mango variety. An excellent source of vitamins A and C. Also provides folate, vitamin E, and fiber.
Unique for being high in healthy monounsaturated fats. An excellent source of potassium, fiber, and vitamins C, E, and K.
Contains papain, an enzyme that aids digestion. An excellent source of vitamin C and a good source of vitamin A (from beta-carotene) and folate.
Contains bromelain, a mixture of enzymes with anti-inflammatory and digestive properties. An excellent source of vitamin C and manganese.
Very high in water content (92%), making it hydrating. A good source of vitamin C and vitamin A. Contains the antioxidant lycopene.
Nutritionally similar to seeded watermelon: high in water, vitamins A and C, and the antioxidant lycopene. The lack of seeds is a convenience trait.
A tropical fruit. A good source of fiber, vitamin A, and various antioxidants. Also provides riboflavin and minerals like phosphorus and potassium.
The aril is a good source of fiber and vitamin C. The peel is rich in xanthones, powerful antioxidants studied for various health benefits.
A tropical fruit related to jackfruit. A good source of energy from carbohydrates. Provides vitamin C, calcium, and iron.
The flesh provides vitamin C and copper. Also contains smaller amounts of other minerals and antioxidants. The seed is not edible.
Known as the "king of fruits." High in energy, fiber, and healthy fats. An excellent source of vitamin C, potassium, and B vitamins.
The flesh is rich in carbohydrates and fiber. A good source of vitamin C, vitamin A, and potassium. The seeds are also edible and nutritious.
A good source of vitamin C and fiber. Contains various plant compounds (annonaceous acetogenins) studied for potential anti-cancer properties.
A complete protein, containing all essential amino acids. Rich in choline (for brain health), lutein/zeaxanthin (for eyes), and vitamins B12 and D.
A complete protein, containing all essential amino acids. Rich in choline (for brain health), lutein/zeaxanthin (for eyes), and vitamins B12 and D.
A complete protein, containing all essential amino acids. Rich in choline (for brain health), lutein/zeaxanthin (for eyes), and vitamins B12 and D.
A complete protein, containing all essential amino acids. Rich in choline (for brain health), lutein/zeaxanthin (for eyes), and vitamins B12 and D.
A complete protein, containing all essential amino acids. Rich in choline (for brain health), lutein/zeaxanthin (for eyes), and vitamins B12 and D.
An oily fish, rich in omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA). An excellent source of protein, vitamin D, vitamin B12, and selenium.
The national fish of the Philippines. A fatty fish, rich in omega-3s and protein. A good source of phosphorus, calcium (from bones), and potassium.
A lean fish. An excellent source of high-quality protein, selenium, and vitamin B12. Also contains some omega-3 fatty acids.
A type of threadfin bream. A lean source of protein. Provides B vitamins, selenium, and phosphorus.
A common and affordable fish. A good source of protein and omega-3 fatty acids. Also provides calcium, phosphorus, and vitamin D.
A type of tuna. A lean source of protein. Rich in selenium, vitamin B12, and provides omega-3 fatty acids.
A firm-fleshed fish. A good source of lean protein, B vitamins, and minerals like phosphorus and selenium.
A lean, white fish with a firm texture. An excellent source of high-quality protein, phosphorus, and selenium.
A large, predatory fish. A good source of protein, niacin, vitamin B12, and selenium. Note: can be high in mercury.
A small, oily fish. A good source of omega-3 fatty acids, protein, calcium (if eaten with bones), and vitamin D.
A popular white fish. A lean source of high-quality protein. Provides potassium, selenium, and vitamin D.
A colorful reef fish. A lean source of protein. Provides various B vitamins and minerals like phosphorus.
A rabbitfish. A good source of protein and omega-3 fatty acids. Also provides calcium and phosphorus.
An oily fish. A good source of omega-3 fatty acids, protein, and vitamin D. Also provides niacin and vitamin B6.
Small, oily fish often eaten whole. An excellent source of omega-3s, calcium, vitamin D, and vitamin B12.
A type of tuna. A lean source of protein. Provides selenium, niacin, and vitamin B12.
A fatty tuna. A good source of omega-3 fatty acids and high-quality protein. Also rich in selenium and vitamin D.
Likely a local fish name. Generally, fish are good sources of protein, B vitamins, and minerals like selenium and iodine.
A lean source of protein. However, it is often high in mercury and other toxins due to bioaccumulation and is not recommended for frequent consumption.
A cartilaginous fish. The meat is lean and a good source of protein. Provides selenium and other minerals.
A good source of high-quality protein. Provides vitamin B12, selenium, and zinc. The liver (aligue) is a delicacy and is high in cholesterol.
A spanner crab or sea cockroach. A delicacy. The meat is a good source of lean protein, iodine, and zinc.
A prized crustacean. The meat is a good source of protein, omega-3 fatty acids, and selenium. The tomalley (liver) is rich but high in cholesterol.
Larger than shrimp. A lean source of protein. Low in fat and a good source of selenium, vitamin B12, and the antioxidant astaxanthin.
Very low in fat and calories. An excellent source of lean protein, selenium, vitamin B12, and the antioxidant astaxanthin.
Low in fat and calories. An excellent source of protein, vitamin B12, riboflavin, and selenium. Contains antioxidants and is a good source of copper.
A large citrus fruit. An excellent source of vitamin C. Also provides fiber, potassium, and antioxidants.
A sweeter pomelo variety. An excellent source of vitamin C and a good source of potassium and fiber.
A specific cultivar of pomelo. Like others, it is rich in vitamin C, antioxidants, and fiber.
A smaller pomelo. Nutritionally similar: high in vitamin C, fiber, and potassium.
An excellent source of vitamin A (from beta-carotene) and vitamin C. Very hydrating due to high water content.
A variety of banana. A good source of potassium, vitamin B6, vitamin C, and dietary fiber.
An easy-to-peel citrus fruit. A good source of vitamin C and fiber. Also provides antioxidants like beta-cryptoxanthin.
The flesh is low in calories and contains prebiotic fiber for gut health. A good source of vitamin C, antioxidants, and iron (especially red varieties).
A ripe, sweet mango variety. An excellent source of vitamins A and C. Also provides folate, vitamin E, and fiber.
Sweet and tender. A good source of fiber, vitamins A and C, and folate. Higher in sugar than mature corn.
A nutritional powerhouse. Excellent source of vitamins C and K. High in fiber, folate, potassium, and sulforaphane, a potent antioxidant.
Likely refers to the shoots or young fronds of a plant, possibly fern. Typically low in calories and a good source of fiber and some minerals.
Likely another type of shoot or young plant stem. Generally provides fiber, some vitamins, and minerals.
A good source of fiber, folate, vitamins A, C, E, and K. Contains the amino acid asparagine and is a natural diuretic.
Leafy greens with a peppery flavor. An excellent source of vitamins K, A, and C. Also provides antioxidants and may have anti-inflammatory effects.
Primarily used as an aromatic herb. It contains citral, a compound with anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties. Not consumed in large quantities.
Likely refers to achar or pickled vegetables. Nutrition depends on the vegetable used. High in sodium due to the pickling process. May provide probiotics.
A concentrated source of plant-based protein, fiber, and complex carbohydrates. Rich in vitamins A, C, K, and B vitamins, and minerals like iron and manganese.
Similar to green mung beans. A good source of protein, fiber, and folate. Also provides iron, magnesium, and potassium.
A type of common bean. An excellent source of fiber, plant-based protein, and folate. Also rich in iron, magnesium, and potassium.
A kidney bean variety. High in fiber, protein, and complex carbs. An excellent source of iron, phosphorus, potassium, and folate.
The basis for tofu and soy milk. A complete protein, containing all essential amino acids. Rich in isoflavones, iron, calcium, and fiber.
Likely refers to lentils. A great source of plant-based protein and fiber. High in folate, iron, and manganese. Cooks faster than other dried legumes.
Likely refers to a variety of lentil. A great source of plant-based protein and fiber. High in folate, iron, and manganese.
Provides sodium, an essential electrolyte for nerve function and fluid balance. Excessive intake is linked to high blood pressure.
Contains piperine, which enhances nutrient absorption and has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties. A good source of manganese and vitamin K.
